Review Recent advances in the preparation of levulinic esters from biomass-derived furanic and levulinic chemical platforms using heteropoly acid (HPA) catalysts Navya Subray Bhat Sib Sankar Mal Saikat Dutta * Department of Chemistry, National Institute of Technology Karnataka (NITK), Surathkal, Mangalore, 575025, Karnataka, India Department of Chemistry National Institute of Technology Karnataka (NITK) Surathkal Mangalore Karnataka 575025 India Department of Chemistry, National Institute of Technology Karnataka (NITK), Surathkal, Mangalore-575025, Karnataka, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The esters of biomass-derived levulinic acid (LA) have several potential applications, including cleaner-burning fuel additive, green solvent, fragrance ingredient, and a renewable chemical intermediate for downstream value addition. The levulinic esters (LEs) can be prepared by the acid-catalyzed alcoholysis of the biomass-derived furanic and levulinic chemical platforms such as LA, furfuryl alcohol (FAL), 5-(hydroxymethyl)furfural (HMF), and angelica lactone (AGL). The acid-catalyzed deconstruction of carbohydrates in an alcoholic medium affords the one-pot preparation of LEs. Choosing the right catalyst is of paramount importance for synthesizing LEs from both the economic and environmental perspectives. In this regard, heteropoly acids (HPAs), a class of polyoxometalates (POMs) bearing protons as the counter cation, have found widespread applications as acid catalysts in various organic transformations. HPAs are blessed with conducive properties such as controlled Brønsted and Lewis acidity, high thermal stability, robust structural features, non-toxic nature, tunable solubility, and less corrosiveness. Over the past several years, HPAs have found extensive applications as efficient and environment-friendly catalysts in biorefinery operations, including the synthesis of LEs. At this juncture, it is imperative to ascertain the achievements in this field to date and re-evaluate the challenges. This review attempts to provide up-to-date information about the preparation of LEs using HPA-based catalysts, critically analyze the literature cited, draw conclusions, and propose future prospects. Keywords Alkyl levulinate Biomass Catalysis Esterification Heteropoly acid Renewable chemistry 1 Introduction One of the major challenges before the industrialized societies today is to cater to the energy and material requirements of its citizens without exhausting the resources of the future generation or causing irreversible environmental damage [1]. At present, an overwhelming majority of the hydrocarbon-based transportation fuels, commodity chemicals, and polymers originate from fossilized carbon sources such as petroleum [2]. However, the ever-increasing demand for petroleum in producing energy and chemicals has burdened its dwindling reserves and intensified the economic, geopolitical, and environmental complications [3]. Besides, the excessive release of CO2 during the combustion of hydrocarbon fuels, which took thousands of years to get fixed by photosynthesis, has caused catastrophic damage to the environment [4]. Therefore, a renewable, carbon-neutral alternative must be explored to supplant petroleum in producing fuels, chemicals, and materials [5,6]. Biomass has been identified as a geographically-diverse, abundant, and inexpensive carbon-based feedstock for the commercially-viable production of transportation fuels and chemicals [7]. The biofuels are considered carbon-neutral since the CO2 released upon their combustion gets fixed by the vegetation within a reasonable time frame [8]. Roughly 80 % of the 160 billion tons of biomass produced annually worldwide is non-food, lignocellulosic biomass [9]. The major components of lignocellulosic biomass are cellulose (35–50 %), hemicellulose (20–30 %), and lignin (15−25 %) [10]. The primary technological challenge to produce biofuels and biochemicals from biomass is fast (hours to days) depolymerization, defunctionalization, and deoxygenation reactions of the biopolymers, which required thousands of years to accomplish by nature [11]. The biomass value addition can be done following the thermal, chemocatalytic, and biotechnological pathways [12–14]. The chemocatalytic processes are fast, feedstock agnostic, selective, and work under energy-economic conditions [15,16]. Catalysis conforms to green chemistry principles for more efficient and safer chemical processes and products [17]. The existing catalysts have been repurposed, and a new generation of robust, selective, and inexpensive catalysts have been developed for the catalytic valorization of biomass [18]. The concomitant hydrolysis and dehydration of cellulose and hemicellulose into furanics under acid catalysis are classic examples of the chemocatalytic value addition of biomass [19]. The acid-catalyzed dehydration of hexose sugars like glucose forms 5-(hydroxymethyl)furfural (HMF), whereas the dehydration of pentoses (e.g., xylose) leads to furfural (Scheme 1 ) [20,21]. HMF can be rehydrated and ring-opened to 4-oxopentanoic acid or levulinic acid (LA) [22]. Furfuryl alcohol (FAL), produced by the catalytic hydrogenation of furfural, can also be transformed into LA using an acid catalyst [23,24]. LA has been identified as one of the top-ten biomass-derived renewable chemicals by the United States Department of Energy (DOE) based on the potential markets of its derivatives [25]. LA can also be formed directly from carbohydrates [26,27]. LA is one of the most prominent biorenewable chemicals in the biorefinery realm that can be upgraded into various products of commercial value, including hydrocarbon fuels, fuel oxygenates, solvents, monomers for polymers, plasticizers, personal care products, and agrochemicals [28]. The alkyl esters of LA have potential applications as a fuel additive, green solvent, fragrance compounds, and chemical intermediate for downstream value addition pathways (Fig. 1 ) [29]. Ethyl levulinate (EL), for example, promotes cleaner combustion, lesser emission, and superior cold-flow properties in fuel blends with petrodiesel and biodiesel [30]. The small-chain (C1-C4) monohydric alkyl alcohols can be sourced from biomass via enzymatic route; therefore, their esters with LA are biorenewable in their entirety [31–33]. A major challenge for the efficient preparation of levulinic esters (LEs) is to develop robust, selective, inexpensive, and eco-friendly catalysts [34]. In this regard, polyoxometalates (POMs) are promising catalysts for the preparation of LEs. The chemical structure of POMs was established as early as 1934, and they have been applied virtually in all areas of chemistry since then [35,36]. They are known for their fascinating physicochemical properties and catalytic activities towards various organic transformations [36,37]. POMs possess well-defined metal oxide nanoclusters, strong Brønsted (as well as Lewis) acidity, low toxicity, and excellent thermal stability [38]. POMs that contain proton(s) as the countercation are known as heteropoly acids (HPAs). HPA contains an atom of p-block elements like P, Si, etc. (heteroatom), metal atoms such as W, Mo, and V (addenda atom), a relatively large number of oxygen atoms connecting the metal atoms, and H+ ions for charge balancing [39]. The best-known compounds of this group are phosphotungstic acid (H3PW12O40, PTA), silicotungstic acid (H4SiW12O40, STA), phosphomolybdic acid (H3PMo12O40, PMA), and silicomolybdic acid (H4SiMo12O40, SMA) [40,41]. PTA is the most frequently used HPA for LE synthesis. PTA is also reported in multiple other names in the literature, such as tungstophosphoric acid (TPA), heterophosphotungstate (HPW), and dodecatungstophosphoric acid (DPTA). A few of the tungsten (W) atoms can be replaced by molybdenum (Mo) atoms (or vice versa) to make mixed acids of more intricated molecular structure [42]. Keggin-type HPAs, an important class of HPAs, have many advantages, including chemical stability and convenient synthesis [43]. The chemical formula of HPAs can be expressed as [XM12O40]n−, where X = P, As, Si and Ge, and M = W and Mo. The homogeneous HPAs (primary structure) are made heterogeneous (secondary structure) by either partially replacing the protons with alkaline metal ions (e.g., Cs+) or transition metal ions or organic ligands [44]. Alternatively, they are anchored to various heterogeneous materials (e.g., silica, zirconia) [45]. The heterogeneous HPA catalysts have increased surface area, better thermal stability, and superior recyclability than their homogeneous counterparts [46]. Over the past several years, HPA-based catalysts are increasingly being used for the value addition of biomass and green synthesis [47]. In the solid forms of HPAs, two types of acidic protons are found. The highly mobile hydrated protons [H(H2O)n]+ enhance the proton conductivity in hydrated HPAs. The less mobile non-hydrated protons are localized either on M = O or/and both edge and corner-sharing bridging oxygens of M-O-M connections [49]. Regardless, both types of protons contribute to the crystal structure formation in the HPAs (Fig. 2 ). The high mobility of the acidic protons makes the HPAs stronger acids (pKH + > 12) than most mineral acids [50]. Moreover, the acidic strength of HPAs depends on the polyanion structure, its constituent elements (hetero and addenda atoms), and the number of hydrated protons. The acid strength of commercial HPAs is in the following order: H3PW12O40 > H4SiW12O40 > H3PMo12O40 > H4SiMo12O40 [51]. The HPAs have found significant applications in the field of catalysis due to their unique properties, mainly electrons and protons transfer/storage ability, thermal stability, solubility in polar solvents, tunable structure, and high Brønsted acidity [52]. HPAs have even been used as a green catalyst for various industrial processes such as the hydration of propylene, oxidation of ethylene to acetic acid, amination of ketones, and polymerization of tetrahydrofuran [36]. Not surprisingly, HPA-based catalysts have already been employed as acid catalysts for the preparation and synthetic upgrading of biomass-derived furanics and LA [47,53]. Many publications have appeared in the literature on the HPA-catalyzed preparation of LEs from LA and various other feedstocks. At this stage, it is necessary to critically review the achievements in this contemporary area of research, analyze the results, identify the challenges, and deliberate on the future directives. This review has summarized the literature on preparing LEs from LA, FAL, and carbohydrates using HPA catalysts. Details of the preparation, properties (e.g., chemical, thermal), catalytic activities (e.g., selectivity), and recyclability of homogeneous and heterogeneous HPA catalysts have been elaborated. Instead of segregating the sections based on the type of HPA catalysts employed, the emphasis is given to the feedstock used for making LEs. This strategy will help to summarize the achievements of synthesizing LEs from various feedstock using HPA-catalysts and also to identify the challenges for further improvements. For example, the esterification of purified LA or FAL to LEs using HPA catalysts is generally cleaner and provides better yields. Besides, the recovery of HPA catalysts from the reaction mixture is relatively more straightforward. However, the processes require prior synthesis and purification of the biomass-derived chemical platforms, increasing the overall cost. The ‘one-pot’ preparation of LEs from carbohydrates or raw biomass using HPA catalysts is a more desirable strategy. However, the process often affords a lesser yield of LEs, and the separation of HPA catalysts from the side products like humin is cumbersome. 2 Preparation of LEs from sugars and carbohydrates using HPA-based catalysts In this section, direct alcoholysis of the biomass-derived sugars and carbohydrates to LEs by the HPA catalysts has been elaborated. The one-pot production of LEs from carbohydrates is particularly interesting since the process does not mandate prior separation and purification of the furanic or levulinic intermediate. In most cases, the homogeneous, water-soluble HPA catalysts were made heterogeneous for superior thermal stability, improved separability from the reaction media, better recyclability, and enhanced selectivity than their homogeneous counterpart. However, the heterogeneous HPA catalysts have challenges associated with them, such as the requirement of using more demanding reaction conditions, leaching of active catalyst from the supporting material, and deactivation of the catalytic sites. HPA catalysts used for the preparation of LEs can be broadly classified into four categories. In the first category, homogeneous HPA catalysts with Keggin or Wells-Dawson (WD) structure are used in the hydrated or anhydrous form. In the second category, the protons of homogeneous HPAs are partially-substituted by suitable metal ions (e.g., alkali metal, transition metal) or organic cation (e.g., ammonium, quaternary ammonium), making them heterogeneous. In the third category, the homogeneous or metal ion-exchanged HPAs are impregnated on a suitable solid support to improve the catalytic activity, recyclability, and stability of the resultant materials. In the fourth category, HPAs are supported on multiple solid materials with intricate molecular structure and designed structural features like magnetic properties, hydrophobicity, and mesoporosity. The table entries in Table 1 (and the subsequent tables) are arranged according to the category of HPA catalyst (as indicated above) used to prepare LEs. Recently, the topotactic transformation of homogeneous heteropoly acid (HPA), namely, phosphotungastomolybdic acid (HPW4Mo10Ox), was converted to heterogeneous by binding with cysteine (HPW4Mo10Ox-Cys) and used as the catalyst for the preparation of LEs. But the homogeneous HPW4Mo10Ox catalyst gave up to 62 % yield of EL at around 86 % conversion of glucose, whereas the heterogeneous HPW4Mo10Ox-Cys catalyst gave only ∼5 % EL at 92 % conversion of glucose [54]. Rataboul and Essayem (2011) converted microcrystalline cellulose into methyl levulinate (ML) in 20 % yield using supercritical methanol (anhydrous or 90 % aq.) and Cs-exchanged Keggin-type HPA catalyst (CsxH3-xPW12O40, x = 2.0 and 2.5). The combination of supercritical methanol and acid catalysts was used to depolymerize and solubilize cellulose, followed by esterification. The Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 catalyst provided 20 % yield of ML [55]. The methanolysis of fructose was carried out in the presence of a Fe-exchanged phosphotungstate (Fe-HPW) catalyst, which was prepared by partially replacing the H+ ions of HPW (heterophosphotungstate, H3PW12O40) with Fe3+ ions. The Fe3+ ions in the HPA framework introduced Lewis acid centers in the catalyst. The synergistic interactions between the Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites in the Fe-HPW-1 (0.38 % of Fe) catalyst afforded up to 73.7 % yield of ML. The catalyst was reused up to five cycles without a significant drop in ML yield [56]. Metal-modified HPW such as Cs-HPW, Ag-HPW, K-HPW, Fe-HPW, and Sn-HPW were used as catalysts for the ethanolysis of fructose into EL. The Ag-HPW-1 and K-HPW-1 catalysts provided EL in 58.1 % and 50.8 % yield, respectively. Furthermore, the effect of co-solvent on EL formation was explored. Toluene was found to work best, affording a 61 % yield of EL, compared to the next best yield of 46 % in 1,4-dioxane. The catalyst was recycled for five consecutive cycles, where the yield marginally decreased to 50 % after the fifth cycle [57]. The titanium-exchanged TPA, such as Ti0.25TPA, Ti0.50TPA, and Ti0.75TPA, were synthesized, characterized, and employed for the one-pot synthesis of EL from sugars. The Ti0.75TPA catalyst provided a 21 % and 63 % yield of EL from glucose and fructose, respectively [58]. Interestingly, the catalyst provided excellent yields of EL (ca. 92–98 %) when LA, FAL, or HMF were used as feedstock. With increase in the extent of Ti-exchange, the yield of EL increased, which was explained by the increased Lewis acidity of the Ti-exchanged TPA catalyst. In 2017, a series of metal-substituted HPWs (HPWM, M = CuII, ZnII, CrIII, FeIII, SnIV, TiIV, and ZrIV) were prepared, and their catalytic activities were studied for the synthesis of ML by conventional as well as by microwave-assisted methanolysis of cellulose [59]. Under conventional heating (160 °C), 51.3 % of ML was obtained after 7 h of reaction, whereas 62.6 % of ML was obtained in 2 h under microwave heating using HPWTi catalyst. The detailed mechanistic studies and intermediate identification showed that the Brønsted to Lewis (B/L) acid ratio in the catalyst affects the selectivity toward ML, and 2.84 was found to be the optimum value in the HPWTi catalyst [59]. The substituted pyridine-exchanged HPW catalysts were prepared using the solvothermal method for the efficient one-pot synthesis of ML from carbohydrates. The catalyst was recycled up to four cycles with 96.7 % mass recovery. The yield of ML decreased to 71.2 % from 82.5 % after the fourth cycle due to leaching of catalyst. The lose of catalytic activity was maybe due to catalyst leaching and deposition of organic species onto the recycled catalyst [60]. The Sn(II)-exchanged HPAs were synthesized, characterized, and their catalytic activity was studied for the ethanolysis of fructose. The most effective Sn2SiW12O40 (SnSiWO) catalyst provided a 61 % yield of EL at 160 °C. The catalyst was reused up to ten consecutive cycles without noticeable loss of activity [61]. In 2019, Zhang et al. reported the synthesis of ML from glucose by conventional as well as microwave heating using bifunctional MPW (metal exchanged HPW, where M = Al3+, In3+, Cr3+, Fe3+) catalysts. The AlPW catalyst performed best, providing around 62.9 mol% ML within 30 min at 160 °C and was recyclable up to five cycles [62]. The Cs10.6[H2.4GeNb13O41] (CsGeNb) catalyst containing Brønsted acid, Lewis acid, and basic sites (trifunctional catalyst) was designed for the one-pot conversion of carbohydrates into ML. The crystalline CsGeNb catalyst had substantially better activity than its structural constituents, such as Nb2O5 and H4GeW12O40. The CsGeNb catalyst provided a maximum of 89.3 % and 85.6 % yields of ML from fructose under microwave and conventional conditions, respectively. The catalyst was recycled up to six catalytic cycles without significant loss of activity [63]. The ionic liquid-based dicationic polyoxometalates (IL-POM) were applied for the conversion of fructose to EL. Among the IL-POM catalysts studied, IL-H3[PW12O40] showed the highest activity compared to IL-H4[SiMo12O40] and IL-H3[PMo12O40] catalysts, which may be explained by the higher acidity of the first catalyst compared to the latter two. After five catalytic cycles, the yield of EL came down from 80 % to 62 %, indicating partial loss of activity by the catalyst [64]. Sun et al. reported the use of micellar WD HPA catalyst (C16TA)xH6-xP2W18O62 (where x = 1–6), prepared by exchanging the H+ of H6P2W18O62 with hexadecyltrimethylammonium chloride (CTAB), for the hydrolysis and alcoholysis of various biomass feedstocks. Up to 58.5 % yield of ML was achieved after 7 h reaction at 160 °C. The result may be explained by the strong acidity of (C16TA)xH6-xP2W18O62 catalyst and the formation of nanoreactor micellar assembly around cellulose that offered more catalytic sites for the reaction [65]. In a later report, ML was prepared from microcrystalline cellulose using various IL-POM catalysts. The sulfonic acid-based (PyPS)3PW12O40 catalyst provided a 71.4 % yield of ML, compared to only 3.6 % ML in the control reaction. The effect of acidity, structure, and solubility of the catalyst on ML yield was studied. The catalyst was successfully recovered even after ten consecutive cycles without a significant dip in ML yield (71.1–57.6 %) [66]. A series of supported HPW catalysts such as HPW/β, HPW/Snβ, HPW/H-Y, HPW/H-ZSM-5, HPW/USY, HPW/ReUSY, and HPW/SBA-15 were synthesized via wet impregnation method for the one-pot preparation of EL from various carbohydrates. Among the synthesized catalysts, 20 wt.% HPW/H-ZSM-5 provided EL in 40.6 % yield within 2 h at 160 °C, whereas the 20 wt.% HPW/Sn β and 20 wt.% HPW/β catalysts provided EL in 24 % and 7 % yield, respectively. The catalyst recyclability was studied up to four cycles. However, after the first cycle, the yield of EL decreased to 32.8 %, owing to the partial leaching of HPW from the supporting material [67]. In the year 2017, Lai et al. supported iron-modified HPW (HPWFe) on mesoporous silica-pillared montmorillonite (MMTSi) through a combination of sol-gel and self-assembly methods to improve the thermal stability and surface area of the catalyst while minimizing the leaching of HPW. Methanolysis of fructose in the presence of the 4-HPWFe-MMTSi (31.78 wt.% of HPWFe) catalyst provided ML in 74 % yield, whereas MMTSi alone provided ML in only a 6.8 % yield. The catalyst was recycled up to five catalytic cycles without any significant loss of activity [68]. The direct synthesis of EL from fructose was also reported using commercially-available HPA catalysts (e.g., STA) supported on carbonaceous materials such as high surface area graphite and activated carbon [69]. A bifunctional catalyst system composed of commercially-available STA as a Brønsted acid and Sn-Beta as a Lewis acid was designed and used for the catalytic transformation of α-cellulose and microcrystalline cellulose into ML. The synergetic effect of Brønsted acidity from STA and Lewis acidity from ZrO2 assisted in ML synthesis [70]. In the same year, Mulik et al. reported the synthesis of EL from glucose by using an 80:20 physical mixture of Zr-exchanged HPW and Sn-Beta (ZrHPW-Sn-beta) as catalyst having both Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites [71]. Table 1 lists the recent literature reporting the direct conversion of biomass-derived carbohydrates into LEs using HPA-based catalysts. The increase in Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites on HPAs made the carbohydrate to LE reaction faster since all the steps (e.g., dehydration, hydrolysis, esterification) involved in the transformation are acid-catalyzed. The reaction generally requires temperature in the range of 120−180 °C, a reaction time of 2−24 h, and the use of excess alcohol reagent. The detailed mechanistic studies revealed that HMF and 5-(alkoxymethyl)furfural (AMF) formed during the reaction as intermediates (Scheme 1), which then underwent acid-catalyzed hydrolysis by ring-opening. Lower reaction temperatures (<80 °C) formed AMFs in appreciable quantities suggesting that the rehydration and consequent ring-opening of AMFs are favored at elevated temperatures. In some instances, the homogeneous HPA catalyst provided comparable or better yields of LEs compared to their heterogeneous counterpart; however, the latter is generally preferred owing to their convenient separation from the reaction mixture and better recyclability. There is a handful of literature available on the direct production of LEs by using metal-ion-exchanged HPW catalysts or HPW immobilized on various supporting materials (e.g., ionic liquids, H-ZSM). The use of fructose and inulin as feedstocks typically resulted in a good yield of LEs due to relatively straightforward dehydration of the fructofuranose form. In contrast, glucose resulted in poor yields of LEs because of the additional glucose-to-fructose isomerization step and the availability of alternative reaction pathways. The use of ionic liquid-based HPA catalysts showed maximum conversion and selectivity towards LEs and good catalyst reusability. However, the IL-based catalysts are generally expensive, and care must be taken to reuse the catalyst for several cycles without loss of mass of the catalyst. The Fe-exchanged HPW catalysts and fluoropyridine-substituted HPW catalysts also gave good yields of EL from fructose and showed good reusability. Although the HPA-catalyzed one-pot preparation of LEs from carbohydrates is an attractive proposition, efficient recovery of the HPA catalysts from the reaction broth containing humin remains a challenge. More research is required to develop HPA-based heterogeneous catalysts with excellent activity and recyclability for the efficient preparation of LEs from biomass-derived sugars and carbohydrates under energy-efficient, eco-friendly conditions. 3 Synthesis of LEs from FAL using HPA-based catalysts Furfural is obtained by the acid-catalyzed dehydration of pentose sugars (e.g., xylose) present in the hemicellulosic fraction of lignocellulosic biomass. LEs can be sourced by the alcoholysis of FAL, prepared by the selective catalytic hydrogenation of biomass-derived furfural under acid catalysis. Therefore, LEs from both the cellulosic fraction and hemicellulosic fraction ensures better utilization of the biomass feedstock. In this part, the preparation of LEs from FAL is discussed using various HPA-based acid catalysts (Scheme 2 ). Rao et al. reported the preparation of Butyl levulinate (BL) from FAL using titanium-exchanged TPA catalysts, where the Ti0.75TPA catalyst provided EL in a 97 % yield after 30 min reaction at 120 °C [58]. The synthesis of BL from FAL was reported using methylimidazolebutylsulfate phosphotungstate ([MIMBS]3PW12O40) as an organic-inorganic hybrid solid acid catalyst. The reaction mechanism was proposed, and 2-butoxymethylfuran was found to be an intermediate for the reaction (Table 2 ). The use of an equivalent of water made the kinetics faster and improved the yield of BL, which was explained by the rate-limiting hydration and ring-opening of angelica lactone (AGL)-like intermediate [72]. In order to expand the reaction scope, various alkyl alcohols were used for the alcoholysis of FAL under refluxing condition. n-Propanol and 2-propanol gave better yields (80 % and 66 %, respectively) compared to other alcohols. A series of catalysts like [MIMBS]3PW12O40, [MIMBS]4SiW12O40, [MIMBS]5BW12O40, and [MIMBS]5AlW12O40 were prepared for the synthesis of BL by the butanolysis of FAL. When reactions were carried out in anhydrous 1-butanol, the yield of BL was only 60 %. However, the addition of an equivalent of water improved the yield to 94 %. The ML, EL, propyl levulinate (PL), and isopropyl levulinate (IPL) were isolated in 43, 59, 67, and 63 % yields, respectively. Reusability and recyclability tests of the catalysts were carried out, and an 81 % yield of BL was obtained even after six catalytic cycles [73]. The TPA supported SBA-16 catalysts were synthesized for the transformation of FAL into BL. Under identical conditions, methanol, ethanol, propanol, and 1-butanol gave 8, 20, 77, and 97 % yield of ML, EL, PL, and BL, respectively. The catalyst was successfully recycled for four consecutive cycles without significant loss of activity [74]. Nandiwale et al. synthesized HPW (5−20 wt.%) anchored on Meso-HZ-5 catalysts, prepared by desilicating H-ZSM-5 using NaOH and then treated with proton-exchanged resin, for the ethanolysis of FAL to EL. Under optimized conditions (120 °C, 5 h, 25 wt.% catalyst, 4 eq. EtOH), 15 wt.% HPW/Meso-HZ-5 showed the best catalytic activity providing 97 % yield of EL at the quantitative conversion of FAL. The catalyst gave a 97 % yield of EL for three consecutive cycles, which then lowered to 84 % on the fourth cycle. The loss of activity was attributed to the blocking of active sites by the intermediates and EL [75]. The selective preparation of BL from FAL was carried out using Zn-exchanged TPA (5−25 wt.%) supported on niobium oxide (Zn1TPA/Nb2O5) as the catalyst. The use of Zn1TPA provided 92 % BL at the quantitative conversion of FAL. However, the catalyst was partially soluble in the reaction mixture that created issues to separate it from the reaction mixture. The heterogeneous 20 wt.% Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 catalyst provided a 94 % yield of BL after 5 h reaction at 110 °C. The catalyst was recycled four times without significant loss of catalytic activity [76]. Recently, Tiwari et al. synthesized Sn-exchanged TPA supported on K-10 for converting FAL to BL in excess 1-butanol. The activity and acidity of the synthesized catalysts were dependent on the extent of the Sn-exchange and the type of clay support. Near-quantitative (ca. 98 %) yield of BL was obtained after 5 h of reaction time at 110 °C using only 1.2 mol% of the Sn1-TPA/K-10 catalyst. The catalyst was successfully recycled for five consecutive cycles [77]. A series of HPW supported on ZrO2 bifunctionalized organosilica nanotubes (PW12/ZrO2-Si(Et)Si-NTs) with varying Si/Zr molar ratios were prepared by the micelle-templated sol-gel co-condensation route and applied for the ethanolysis of FAL. Under optimized conditions (120 °C, 3 h), 74 % EL was obtained using only 1.5 wt.% of the catalyst PW12/ZrO2-Si(Et)Si-NTs1.0. The excellent activity of nanocatalyst was explained by the combination of strong Brønsted and Lewis acidity, hollow tubular nanostructure, and hydrophobic surface. The catalyst was successfully recovered and reused three times without significant loss of activity. The addition of a small amount of water to ethanolic solution accelerated the kinetics and provided a marginally higher yield of EL compared to the control reaction (water-free system) [78]. As apparent from Table 2, EL and BL were prepared in excellent yields from FAL using metal ion-exchanged and supported HPA catalysts. The reaction temperature of 110−120 °C was routinely used to overcome the kinetic barrier in the ring-opening alcoholysis reaction. The reactions were either conducted under reflux (in the case of 1-butanol) or in a closed reactor (in the case of ethanol). In some cases, the use of a small amount of water improved the yield of LEs due to assistance in the ring-opening reaction. Catalysts like PW12/ZrO2-Si(Et)Si-NTs1.0 required only a small loading (1.5 wt.%), whereas Zn1TPA/Nb2O5 required very high loading (>300 wt.%) of catalyst. The result may be explained by the concentration of Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites on the catalyst. Since HPA-based catalysts are relatively more expensive than mineral acids and other solid acid catalysts, care must be taken to develop HPA catalysts that work efficiently even under low loading. The reactions required several hours (ca. 5−12 h) to complete, and faster kinetics without sacrificing the selectivity and yield of product (i.e., LEs) would be advantageous for the process economy. 4 Synthesis of LEs from AGL and HMF using HPA-based catalysts The intramolecular lactonization of LA forms angelica lactones (AGLs) as a mixture of isomers (α, β, and γ). The reaction is generally conducted under reduced pressure, where AGL distills out along with water (the byproduct) from unreacted LA. The reaction is promoted by an acid catalyst and excellent yields have been obtained using inexpensive heterogeneous catalysts. The alcoholysis of AGLs under acid catalysts can be a convenient way of synthesizing LEs. On the other hand, acid-catalyzed dehydration of hexose sugars and carbohydrates form HMF. The acid-catalyzed alcoholysis of HMF leads to LEs along with an equimolar quantity of formate ester. The volatile formate ester is typically distilled off during the purification of LEs. The Cu-based metal-organic framework (MOF) supported POM, [Cu-BTC][PMA] (BTC = benzene-1,3,5-carboxylate, PMA = phosphomolybdic acid) catalyst was used for the synthesis of EL from HMF. The [Cu-BTC][PMA] catalyst led to the quantitative conversion of HMF but afforded only a 20.2 % yield of EL along with 68.4 % of 5-(ethoxymethyl)furfural (EMF). The catalyst was recycled and reused up to five cycles without drastic loss of activity [79]. The choline chloride (ChCl) exchanged WD HPA catalysts ChxH(6-x)P2W18O62 (x = 1–6) were employed for the synthesis of BL from LA-derived α-AGL. The mechanistic studies revealed that the formation of more pseudo butyl levulinate was due to reaction pathway 1 (Scheme 3 ). The formation of small amounts of LA during the reaction was because of reaction pathway 2 or via the hydrolysis of BL. The acidity of catalysts played a guiding role in their efficiency of catalyzing the esterification reaction. For example, Ch1H5P2W18O62 afforded an 84.5 % yield of BL, whereas Ch5HP2W18O62 gave only a 9.9 % yield of BL. This result can be correlated with the number of protons available per mole of the catalyst. Furthermore, the catalysts were successfully reused for five catalytic cycles [80]. 5 Synthesis of LEs from LA by using HPA-based catalysts The most-studied process for the preparation of LEs is the esterification of LA using the Fischer esterification protocol. The reversible process esterifies LA in excess alcohol using a suitable acid catalyst. In general, the reaction is performed at an elevated temperature under conventional heating. Both open reactor and sealed vessel have been employed and gave comparable yields. Water formation as the byproduct makes the process reversible; therefore, water is often removed by azeotrope formation, and the alcoholic reagent is used in excess. There are several reports on the esterification of LA to LEs using HPA-based catalysts (Table 3 ). LEs were synthesized from LA at room temperature using homogeneous catalysts like STA. Though the primary alcohols gave good yields (>80 %) of LEs, the secondary alcohols did not perform well. The authors concluded that despite having less acidity than PTA, STA showed better catalytic activity due to higher softness of the SiW12O40 4− anion, which stabilized the protonated intermediate formed in the LA esterification. The aqueous layer was evaporated to get the catalyst back and reused up to three catalytic cycles [81]. In 2019, we reported the synthesis of LEs from LA using commercially-available HPA catalysts. The reactions were conducted in a sealed glass reactor, and the LEs were isolated in >85 % yields. The catalyst was precipitated from the reaction mixture by adding a non-polar solvent. The catalysts were recycled and reused up to three cycles without significant loss of either mass or catalytic activity [82]. Ahmed et al. studied the effect of microwave and conventional heating methods on EL synthesis using a homogeneous STA catalyst. The kinetic modeling suggested that the esterification of LA follows a pseudo-first-order reaction mechanism. The activation energy of the reaction was 44–45 KJ/mol. Interestingly, the conversion of LA was noticeably higher under microwave heating compared to conventional heating [83]. The same research group studied the role of alcohol reagent in the esterification of LA. The activation energy for ethanol using heterophosphomolybdic acid (HPM, same as PMA) catalyst was found to be 42.4 ± 5 kJ/mol. The activation energies were slightly more in the case of 1-propanol (46.1 ± 5 kJ/mol) and 1-butanol (53.5 ± 3 kJ/mol). The activation energy for EL in the case of HPW catalyst was less (23.8 ± 5 kJ/mol) when compared to HPM catalyst [84]. The Ti-exchanged TPA catalysts were prepared for the synthesis of LEs from LA. EL was obtained in a 98 % yield within 30 min at 120 °C using 2.25 wt.% of the Ti0.75TPA catalyst [58]. ZrxTPA (x = 0.25, 0.5, 0.75) catalysts yielded nearly 99 % of EL after 2 h at 120 °C. The reaction was conducted in a pressure tube using excess ethanol, and the catalyst was reused up to four catalytic cycles without significant loss of activity. The process was then successfully extended to prepare other LEs. ML, IPL, and BL were obtained in 91 %, 79 %, and 90 % yield, respectively. The primary alcohols provided noticeably better yields of LEs compared to secondary alcohol due to the steric issue [85]. Luan et al. prepared the combination of SMA with quinaldic acid (QA), quinoline (QL4), 8-hydroxy-2-methyl quinoline (HMQ4), nicotinic acid N-oxide (NAN4), or cesium carbonate (Cs) named as QA4-SMA, QL4-SMA, HMQ4-SMA, NAN4-SMA, and Cs1H3SMA respectively. Excellent yields (>96 %) of LEs were obtained using C1-C4 alcohols under reflux using 4.0 mol% of the QA4-SMA catalyst. The catalyst was recycled up to five cycles, and there was no significant decrease in the catalytic activity (90.5 % after five cycles) [86]. The ammonium and silver co-doped HPW-like (NH4)0.5Ag0.5H2PW and (NH4)1H2PW were prepared, and they got 99.0 % and 95.5 % of BL, respectively, with 100 % conversion. There was no significant loss in the catalyst activity up to three catalytic cycles [87]. Guo et al. synthesized metal-organic framework (MOF) supported on PMA ([Cu-BTC][PMA]) catalyst for the esterification of LA to EL. A nearly quantitative yield of EL was ensured under the optimized reaction conditions (120 °C, 6 h) [88]. WD PTA incorporated in the silica framework (WD-S) was prepared by the sol-gel method and used as a recyclable catalyst for EL production [89]. The batch reaction was conducted under refluxing conditions in the presence of excess ethanol and only 0.5 mol% WD-S catalyst providing a 76 % yield of EL after 10 h of reaction. Dharne and Bokade carried out the esterification of LA using dodecaphosphotungstic acid (DPTA, same as PTA) supported on montmorillonite (K10) clay catalyst, prepared by the wet impregnation method. BL was isolated in a 97 % yield when the reaction was conducted at 120 °C for 4 h using 10 wt.% (compared to LA) of 20 %DPTA/K10 catalyst and a 1-butanol to LA molar ratio of 6:1. The catalyst was successfully used up to three cycles, and after that drastic decrease in yield was observed due to the leaching of DPTA from the K10 support [90]. The DPTA supported on desilicated H-ZSM-5 (DPTA/DH-ZSM-5) catalysts were prepared through incipient wetness technique. The 15 wt.% DPTA/H-ZSM-5 catalyst afforded a conversion of 94 % with 100 % selectivity. The reactions were studied by kinetic modeling, and the catalyst was recycled for four cycles [91]. STA supported on mesoporous SiO2 catalysts were synthesized, and 20 wt.% of STA-SiO2 gave 73 % yield of ML with 79 % conversion of LA. An attempt to recycle the catalyst showed a marginal lowering in the yield of EL (60 to 56 %) after the first cycle. Interestingly, no significant loss of catalyst activity was there in the consecutive cycles (up to 4th) [92]. STA supported on the silica-gel sphere (SGS) were prepared via incipient wetness technique and used as a catalyst to prepare LEs. A 97 % yield of EL was ensured after 4 h at 84 °C using eight equivalents of ethanol and 20 mol% of the catalyst [93]. HPW-supported ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method and employed to catalyze EL preparation from LA. When the reaction was conducted for 3 h at 150 °C using 40 % HPW/ZrO2 catalyst, EL was obtained in yields as high as 99 % [94]. The HPW/Zr catalyst, prepared by impregnating 15, 20, and 25 wt.% HPW on zirconia was applied for the preparation of EL. The heterogeneous 20-HPW/Zr catalyst showed excellent recyclability up to five cycles [95]. STA supported on ZrO2 were synthesized, characterized, and applied for the preparation of EL from LA. The catalyst afforded >90 % EL within 30 min at 110 °C under microwave heating. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson kinetic studies revealed that the esterification of LA followed first-order kinetics [96]. STA was supported on molecular sieves [MCM-41] to catalyze the preparation of LEs from LA. The catalysts (5−45 wt.% STA/MCM-41) allowed quantitative conversion of LA in the case of hexyl levulinate (HL) [97]. A series of HPW supported on mesoporous MCM-41 catalysts were synthesized and applied for the preparation of EL from LA. The conversion of LA improved with the loading of HPW from 5−45 wt.% and reached maximum 83.7 % when the reaction was conducted at 80 °C for 10 h using 0.4 g catalyst loading (for 48.6 mmol LA) and the ethanol to LA molar ratio of 2.5. The effect of various reaction parameters like reaction temperature, duration, catalyst loading, and ethanol to LA molar ratio were studied. The LA conversion decreased from 75 % to 69 % in the second cycle for the 25 wt.% HPW/MCM-41 catalyst due to partial leaching of HPW from the support [98]. HPW supported on Al-exchanged MCM-41 catalysts were synthesized via impregnation method for the conversion of LA to HL. The quantitative conversion was achieved after 10 h at 100 °C. The catalyst was successfully recycled and reused for up to six consecutive cycles [99]. M. Wu et al. synthesized a porous 3D graphene aerogel-supported HPW catalyst that provided 89.1 % conversion of LA. However, the conversion of LA decreased to only 50 % after five cycles [100]. The decrease in activity was attributed to HPW leaching from the graphene aerogel support during reaction or during washing with polar solvents like ethanol and water. Manikandan and Cheralathan prepared PTA on silicalite-1 (HPA/C-Sil-1) having intracrystalline nanovoids by adding corn pith powder into the zeolite synthesis gel. The temperature-programed desorption of NH3 experiment showed that the acid sites are weakened due to supporting HPA on siliceous zeolite. The interaction between HPA and C-Sil-1 was more than HPA and Sil-1 (no corn pith). The HPA/C-Sil-1 catalyst was used for the preparation of PL and recycled for four consecutive cycles without decrease in activity or observable leaching of HPA [101]. Aluminium-exchanged mesoporous siliceous SBA-15 was used as the supporting material for HPW, PMA, and STA catalysts for preparing EL from LA. The use of STA/AlSBA-15, HPW/AlSBA-15, PMA/AlSBA-15, and AlSBA-15 catalysts afforded EL in 87.4, 81.2, 74.2, and 25.4 % yield, respectively [102]. A series of Ce-exchanged HPW supported on silica gel pellets were prepared to catalyze EL synthesis in a continuous fixed-bed reactor. The 30 wt.% CeHPW/SGP catalyst gave 98.5 % conversion of LA and 99.5 % selectivity towards EL whereas the 30 wt.% CsHPW/SGP and 30 wt.% LaHPW/SGP gave 83.0 % and 85.5 % yield of EL, respectively. The catalyst was stable and did not lose activity even after 40 h of reaction [103]. The Sn-modified STA supported on Ta2O5 was prepared and used as a catalyst to prepare EL from LA. A maximum of 78 % EL was obtained, which decreased to 68 % after the third catalytic cycle [104]. Unlu and Hilmioglu synthesized ZrO2-supported tungstosilicic acid (synonymous to STA) on hydroxyethyl cellulose membrane through solution casting method for EL production. The conversion of LA reached 86 % under optimized conditions, and the catalyst was stable up to five catalytic cycles [105]. Su et al. prepared HPW supported on mesoporous zirconia decorated with benzene-bridged organo-silica (HPW/ZrO2–Si(Ph)Si) and used the novel material as catalyst to prepare ML from LA in near quantitative yield. The excellent catalytic activity was attributed to the strong acidity, mesoporous nature, and surface hydrophobicity of the catalyst. The catalyst could be reused up to three cycles without significant loss of catalytic activity [106]. A series of HPW catalysts supported on ZrO2 and organosilica bridged moiety (HPW/ZrO2-Si(R)) were prepared through the sol-gel co-condensation hydrothermal method and the catalysts such as HPW/ZrO2–Si(Ph)Si-1.0, HPW/ZrO2–Si(Et)Si-1.0, and HPW/ZrO2–Si(Ph)-1.0 afforded ML in 99.9, 72, and 83.8 % yields, respectively. The process was extended to prepare other LEs, where EL and BL were obtained in 91.5 % and 82.8 % yields, respectively under optimised conditions (65 °C, 3 h). Catalyst recyclability and reusability were studied for up to three cycles [107]. HPW and Zirconia bifunctionalized organosilica nanotubes (HPW/ZrO2-Et-HNSn) with varying molar ratios of Zr/Si were prepared by co-hydrolysis and co-condensation methods. When the reactions were carried out using catalysts like HPW/ZrO2-Et-HNS-1.0, HPW/ZrO2-Et-HNS-1.5, HPW/ZrO2-Et-HNS-2.0, and HPW/ZrO2-Et-3Dint, ML was isolated in 78, 85, 89, and 92 % yield, respectively. The higher catalytic activity of the HPW/ZrO2-Et-3Dint catalyst was attributed to the greater density of Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst. Furthermore, the performance of HPW/ZrO2-Et-HNS-2.0 was compared with other catalysts like HPW/ZrO2-2Dhex2.0, HPW/ZrO2, HPW, Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40, ZrO2, and Amberlyst-10. The catalysts were successfully recycled three times without significant loss of activity [108]. HPW supported on zirconia bifunctionalized organosilica nanotubes (HPW/ZrO2-Si(Et)Si-NTS) were synthesized by the sol-gel co-condensation method. Higher loadings (> 12 wt.%) of HPW provided better yields of EL. The Zr/Si molar ratio also played a crucial role on EL yield. The HPW/ZrO2-Si(Et)Si-NTS1.0 catalyst tolerated water owing to their surface hydrophobicity, and a similar yield of EL (ca. 97.4 %) was obtained compared to a water-free reaction medium. The catalyst was recyclable for three consecutive cycles without significantly losing the activity [78]. S. An et al. prepared HPW supported niobium oxide fabricated with organosilica benzene and biphenyl bridged moieties (HPW/Nb2O5-Si(Ph)Si), difunctionalized catalyst by using by sol-gel method for ML preparation. The excellent catalytic activity was due to porosity and hydrophobic surface of the catalysts, also due to combination of strong Brønsted acidity and moderate Lewis acidity of the hybrid catalyst. The catalyst was recycled up to three cycles without drastic loss of activity [109]. The HPW-anchored SiO2@graphene aerogel 3D porous catalysts showed 92.4 % conversion of LA. However, the conversion dropped drastically to only 34.6 % in the second cycle. Afterward, the conversion remained nearly the same till the fifth cycle. The catalyst was deactivated due to the leaching of HPW from the supporting support [110]. The Keggin-type HPAs were immobilized on mesoporous silica-coated magnetite particles with a core-shell structure (Fe3O4@SiO2@SiO2/TPA), and their catalytic activity was studied for the synthesis of BL from LA. The catalyst was stable up to four cycles [111]. As seen in Table 3, both homogeneous and heterogeneous HPA catalysts have been used to prepare LEs starting from LA. Very low loading of strongly-acidic HPA catalysts such as STA was able to provide EL in excellent yield. However, homogeneous HPA catalysts suffer from recyclability issues. HPA catalysts with strongly Lewis acidic metal sites such as SnSTA/Ta2O5 also showed good activity. However, the HPA catalysts with a limited number of acidic sites required larger loading for satisfactory yields. 6 Synthesis of LEs from xylose and furfural by using HPA-based bifunctional catalysts Direct preparation of LEs from xylose and furfural has also been attempted. The reaction requires a catalyst having both metal sites (for catalytic hydrogenation of furfural to FAL) and acidic sites (for dehydration of xylose to furfural and the alcoholysis of FAL to LEs). Zhu et al. synthesized LEs directly from furfural in the presence of alcohol using a metal-acid bifunctional catalyst without using an external hydrogen source. Au-H4SiW12O40 supported on ZrO2 was used as a catalyst for the preparation of LEs starting from furfural. The process used an alcohol reagent for the esterification reaction and also as a hydrogen donor molecule. The process afforded a maximum of 80.2 % yield of PL under optimized conditions [112]. Recently, the direct conversion of xylose to LEs was carried out using a combination of Zr-MCM-41 and HPW catalyst. A maximum of 46.4 % of BL was obtained after 10 h at 150 °C, where 1-butanol acted as a hydrogen donor solvent [113]. The direct preparation of LEs from furfural or xylose is economically attractive since it avoids additional steps of preparing and purifying FAL. However, the reported processes used alcohols as the hydrogen donor solvent for transfer hydrogenation. Therefore, the alcohols will themselves get oxidized to aldehydes, which may lead to the formation of side products or put hurdles during the purification of LEs. The use of molecular hydrogen as the reducing agent is likely to be less expensive and more convenient. However, care must be taken in designing the catalyst and the reaction conditions to avoid over-reduction of furfural. 7 Conclusion The HPA-based acid catalysts have received significant interest over the past decade to prepare levulinic acid esters directly from carbohydrates or from biomass-derived furanic and levulinic chemical platforms. Excellent selectivity and yields of LEs have been achieved using both homogeneous and heterogeneous HPA catalysts. Heterogeneous HPA catalysts are preferred since they have superior thermal stability and higher surface area than their homogeneous counterpart. Besides, the heterogeneous HPA catalysts can be conveniently separated from the polar reaction mixture and recycled. The supporting material of the HPA catalyst often introduces unique features to the catalyst, including porosity, Lewis acidic sites, and other synergistic interactions that improved the selectivity and yield of LEs. Many of the HPA catalysts show excellent reusability for several catalytic cycles without significant loss of activity. The recyclability of HPA catalysts is particularly pronounced when purified furanic or levulinic intermediate is used as the starting material for the esterification or alcoholysis reaction. However, a one-pot preparation of LEs directly from carbohydrates or cellulosic biomasses is the ultimate goal for notable economic incentives and better scalability of the process. The recyclability of HPA catalysts is more challenging in this case due to the formation of intractable side products such as humin. Regardless, the loss of HPA catalysts' activity was observed due to the leaching of active catalyst from the supporting material, fouling and poisoning of the active sites, and physical loss during their separation from the aqueous/alcoholic reaction media. The reactions can be successfully conducted under conventional as well as microwave heating in the batch or continuous reactors. It is anticipated that more efficient and eco-friendly HPA-based catalysts, which allow the preparation of LEs selectively from a diverse range of starting materials under relatively mild reaction conditions, will continue to be developed in the near future. The successful use of HPA catalysts to prepare LEs will encourage exploring the same catalysts in other biomass value addition processes. 8 Catalyst design and future direction Both homogeneous and heterogeneous HPA catalysts have shown comparable performance to that of mineral acids to synthesize LEs from a diverse-range of feedstock. Although structurally simpler homogeneous HPAs generally provided satisfactory yields of LEs under moderate reaction conditions, the recovery and recycling of catalysts remain a challenge. On the other hand, the heterogeneous HPA catalysts have exhibited promising catalytic activity and often more preferred over their homogeneous counterpart. The homogeneous HPAs are made heterogeneous by either supporting on a suitable solid support (e.g., silica, Nb2O5) or by partially-substituting the protons with metal ions (e.g., Cs+ ion) or organic cations (e.g., quaternary ammonium ion). However, the HPA-based catalysts are relatively more expensive than many mineral and solid acid catalysts. Therefore, it is imperative to keep the catalyst loading as low as possible without slowing down the rate of reaction or compromising on the yield of LEs. The catalyst must have high thermal stability since the recovered catalyst may be required to be calcined at elevated temperatures to remove deposits blocking the active sites. An impeccable balance between the Brønsted and Lewis acidity of the catalyst plays a crucial role in product selectivity. In some cases, multi-tasking HPA-based catalysts were developed wherein an active metal component helped in the catalytic hydrogenation or transfer hydrogenation process. Therefore, a one-pot transformation of xylose or furfural into LEs was successfully achieved. Most of the processes used large excess of the alcohol reagent. The use of excess alcohol requires additional steps for the purification of LEs and recovery of unreacted alcohol. The methods that use equivalent or only slight excess of the alcohol reagent are preferred. The formation of ether and olefins by acid-catalyzed dehydration of alkyl alcohols, especially at elevated temperatures, remains a challenge for the process. Leaching of HPAs from the supporting material is a commonly encountered problem. Therefore, the chosen supporting materials must enable strong interactions with the HPAs. Porosity and surface area of the catalyst play important roles in the kinetics since they determine the number of acid sites available for the chemical transformations. In this regard, coordination between computational and experimental research is desired to understand the molecular-level interactions between HPA and various supporting materials better. Moreover, a detailed understanding of the mechanistic routes adopted by the HPA-based catalysts during the preparation of LEs from various starting materials and under varying reaction conditions is warranted. Therefore, it can be safely concluded that more dedicated efforts are required in this field, which may be accomplished by the active collaboration between the subject experts of HPA and biorefinery research. As discussed earlier, HPA catalysts with varying structural motifs and designed characteristics have been employed for the preparation of LEs from the diverse feedstock. HPA catalysts with more complex structural features such as multiple supporting materials with molecular-level interactions introduce additional characteristics (e.g., porosity) into the catalyst. In some cases, the incorporation of organic groups on the supporting material invoked surface hydrophobicity to expel the water byproduct and minimize leaching. However, while designing the HPA catalysts, both the economic and environmental factors must be taken into consideration. While the design and use of HPA catalysts with multiple structural features are impressive in the academic setting, the cost of producing those catalysts may be unsustainable from the commercial perspective. The catalyst loading is also a crucial aspect of process economics. Although many HPA catalysts worked well in as low as 0.1 mol% loadings, some required a significant amount of catalyst (ca. 20 mol%) for faster kinetics and better yields of LEs. Since water is often formed as a byproduct (e.g., esterification of LA), the leaching of active catalyst from the supporting material remains a challenge. Besides, the use of excess alcohol reagent mandates their recovery after reaction and for purifying LEs. The reaction generally requires a few hours to reach equilibrium at an elevated temperature under conventional heating. The use of microwave heating makes the kinetics noticeably faster. Future research in this area should focus on using crude feedstock containing impurities like formic acid and water. The use of crude feedstock will avoid energy-intensive purification of intermediates like FAL, HMF, and LA and minimize the cost of producing LEs from biomass. It can be safely concluded that a trade-off between efficiency and cost of HPA catalyst used to prepare LEs is desirable if the process aspires to commercialization. coredata.dc:description: The esters of biomass-derived levulinic acid (LA) have several potential applications, including cleaner-burning fuel additive, green solvent, fragrance ingredient, and a renewable chemical intermediate for downstream value addition. The levulinic esters (LEs) can be prepared by the acid-catalyzed alcoholysis of the biomass-derived furanic and levulinic chemical platforms such as LA, furfuryl alcohol (FAL), 5-(hydroxymethyl)furfural (HMF), and angelica lactone (AGL). The acid-catalyzed deconstruction of carbohydrates in an alcoholic medium affords the one-pot preparation of LEs. Choosing the right catalyst is of paramount importance for synthesizing LEs from both the economic and environmental perspectives. In this regard, heteropoly acids (HPAs), a class of polyoxometalates (POMs) bearing protons as the counter cation, have found widespread applications as acid catalysts in various organic transformations. HPAs are blessed with conducive properties such as controlled Brønsted and Lewis acidity, high thermal stability, robust structural features, non-toxic nature, tunable solubility, and less corrosiveness. Over the past several years, HPAs have found extensive applications as efficient and environment-friendly catalysts in biorefinery operations, including the synthesis of LEs. At this juncture, it is imperative to ascertain the achievements in this field to date and re-evaluate the challenges. This review attempts to provide up-to-date information about the preparation of LEs using HPA-based catalysts, critically analyze the literature cited, draw conclusions, and propose future prospects.
coredata.dc:title: Recent advances in the preparation of levulinic esters from biomass-derived furanic and levulinic chemical platforms using heteropoly acid (HPA) catalysts
